metadata.title: NBA CBA Study Materials - Batch 12: Article VII Part 2 - Advanced Salary Cap & Trade Rules
metadata.importance: CRITICAL - Advanced cap mechanics for trades and transactions

studyNote: This covers advanced salary cap topics including salary matching in trades, trade exceptions, cap holds, simultaneous transactions, and the complex rules that govern how teams can execute trades while managing the cap.

questions.question: What is the basic salary matching rule for teams over the cap making trades?
options: Must match salaries within 125% + $100K or 100% based on total
questions.explanation: Teams over the cap must match within specific thresholds: 125% + $100K for smaller trades, or within defined bands for larger trades.

questions.question: If a team is under the salary cap, must they match salaries in trades?
options: No, can take on any amount up to their cap space
Cannot make trades while under cap
questions.explanation: Teams with cap room don't need to match salaries. They can acquire more salary than they send out, up to their available cap space.

questions.question: For teams over the cap trading salaries between $6.5M-$19.6M, what's the matching requirement?
options: Incoming salary cannot exceed outgoing by more than $5 million
questions.explanation: For this salary range, teams can take back the outgoing salary plus $5 million. This is one of the salary matching tiers.

questions.question: What is a 'traded player exception'?
options: Cap exception created when trading away more salary than received
questions.explanation: When a team trades away more salary than it receives, it creates a traded player exception equal to the difference, usable to acquire players later.

questions.question: Can multiple trade exceptions be combined to acquire a player?
options: No, only one exception per transaction
questions.explanation: Trade exceptions cannot be combined. Each can only be used individually in separate transactions.

questions.question: What is a 'cap hold'?
options: Amount teams must keep in reserve
Placeholder salary for unsigned players that counts against the cap
questions.explanation: Cap holds are placeholder amounts for unsigned free agents, retired players, and empty roster spots that count against a team's cap until resolved.

questions.question: What is the cap hold amount for a team's own free agent?
options: Based on their previous salary and FA status (varies: 190%, 150%, 130%, etc.)
questions.explanation: Cap holds for free agents are calculated as percentages of prior salary, varying by free agent classification and salary level.

questions.question: How can a team remove a cap hold?
questions.explanation: Teams can renounce a player's rights to remove their cap hold, but this means losing Bird Rights and any ability to re-sign them over the cap.

questions.question: Can a team use a trade exception to acquire a player making more than the exception amount?
options: No, player's salary cannot exceed the exception
questions.explanation: Trade exceptions can only be used to acquire players whose salary fits entirely within the exception amount. They cannot be exceeded.

questions.question: What is 'simultaneous trade' aggregation?
options: Combining salaries from multiple outgoing players in a single trade
questions.explanation: Teams can aggregate (combine) the salaries of multiple players being traded away to match the incoming salary in a single transaction.

questions.question: Can recently signed free agents be aggregated in trades?
options: No, players signed within the same league year cannot be aggregated together
questions.explanation: Players signed as free agents in the same league year cannot be aggregated together in trades, preventing salary matching manipulation.

questions.question: What is the minimum roster charge?
options: Empty roster spots count as minimum salary cap charges
questions.explanation: Teams with fewer than 12 players have cap charges for the empty roster spots equal to the minimum salary, ensuring teams can't gain cap space by having incomplete rosters.

questions.question: Can traded players be aggregated with a trade exception?
options: No, cannot combine player salaries with exceptions
questions.explanation: Trade exceptions cannot be combined with outgoing player salaries. They must be used independently.

questions.question: What is 'salary matching' in the context of sign-and-trades?
options: More restrictive rules apply to sign-and-trades
questions.explanation: Sign-and-trades have additional restrictions beyond normal trades, including hard cap triggers and base year compensation rules.

questions.question: What is 'base year compensation' (BYC)?
options: Special salary calculation for recently extended players in trades
questions.explanation: BYC applies to players traded during the season they signed an extension. Their outgoing salary for matching purposes is calculated differently (usually 50% of new salary or prior salary, whichever is greater).

questions.question: When does base year compensation apply?
options: Only when trading a player during the same league year they signed an extension
questions.explanation: BYC applies when a player is traded in the same league year they signed a contract extension that increased their salary significantly.

questions.question: Does using a trade exception hard-cap a team?
options: No, trade exceptions don't trigger the hard cap
questions.explanation: Using a trade exception does not trigger the hard cap (unlike using the Non-Taxpayer MLE or executing certain sign-and-trades).

questions.question: What is the 'over the cap' trade rule for teams more than $19.6M over?
options: Can only take back 120% of outgoing salary
Can take back up to 125% + $100K of outgoing salary
questions.explanation: For teams significantly over the cap (outgoing salary > $19.6M), they can take back up to 125% of outgoing salary plus $100K.

questions.question: Can a team trade cash and still use a trade exception in the same deal?
questions.explanation: Teams can include cash (up to $5M per year) in trades using exceptions, as long as the player salary fits within the exception.

questions.question: What happens to a trade exception if partially used?
options: Remainder can be used in future trades
Full exception must be used at once
questions.explanation: Trade exceptions must be used in full for a single player. They cannot be partially used or split across multiple transactions.

questions.question: Can a team over the luxury tax apron use a large trade exception?
options: Yes, but cannot go above the hard cap if one exists
No, cannot use exceptions over apron
questions.explanation: Teams can use trade exceptions even when over the tax apron, unless they're hard-capped (which would prevent going above the hard cap level).

questions.question: What is a 'disabled player exception'?
options: Special cap exception when a player suffers season-ending injury
questions.explanation: When a player suffers a season or career-ending injury, teams may apply for a disabled player exception to sign a replacement (typically for 50% of injured player's salary or the MLE, whichever is less).

questions.question: Can teams aggregate minimum salary players in trades without restriction?
options: Yes, minimum players can be aggregated freely
Only if trading to teams under the cap
questions.explanation: Even minimum salary players are subject to the same aggregation rules (cannot aggregate recently signed free agents from same league year).

questions.question: What is the salary matching rule for teams trading away $6.5M or less?
options: Can take back 175% of outgoing salary
Can take back up to 200% of outgoing salary plus $250K
Can take back outgoing salary plus $5M
questions.explanation: For small trades (under $6.5M outgoing), teams can receive up to 200% of outgoing salary plus $250K, the most lenient matching threshold.

questions.question: Can a team create a trade exception by trading a draft pick?
questions.explanation: Trade exceptions are only created when trading away player salary. Draft picks have no salary value for exception purposes.

questions.question: What is the 'apron' in salary cap terms?
options: Hard cap level ($17.5M above tax line) that limits certain teams
questions.explanation: The apron is a hard cap level set at approximately $17.5M above the luxury tax line. Teams that use certain exceptions or engage in sign-and-trades cannot exceed this.

questions.question: Which transactions trigger the hard cap at the apron?
options: Using Non-Taxpayer MLE, Bi-Annual Exception, or sign-and-trades over certain amounts
questions.explanation: Using the Non-Taxpayer MLE, Bi-Annual Exception, or executing certain sign-and-trades triggers a hard cap at the apron level for that season.

questions.question: Can teams exceed the apron if hard-capped after trades?
options: No, absolutely cannot exceed once hard-capped
questions.explanation: Once a team triggers the hard cap, they cannot exceed the apron level for any reason for the remainder of that league year, including through trades.

questions.question: Does the hard cap carry over to the next season?
options: Yes, until team gets under it
questions.explanation: The hard cap only applies for the league year in which it was triggered. It resets on July 1, though a team can trigger it again the following year.

questions.question: In a 3-team trade, how is salary matching calculated?
options: Each team must independently satisfy matching rules
questions.explanation: In multi-team trades, each team must independently satisfy salary matching rules based on what they're sending out and receiving, as if they were making separate 2-team trades.
